channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Anticorruption Campaign Targets Second CCTV Head
item.description: Liu Wen, the director of China Central Television’s documentary channel, CCTV-9, and producer of the hit series “A Bite of China,” has been detained on suspicion of corruption.
item.dc:creator: By MIA LI

item.title: Uganda Anti-Gay Law Struck Down by Court
item.description: The court ruled on narrow technical grounds, preserving the possibility that the measure could be altered and revived.
item.dc:creator: By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: African Leaders and W.H.O. Intensify Effort to Combat Ebola Virus
item.description: Leaders of the affected countries and the head of the World Health Organization were to initiate a $100 million plan to combat the disease.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Disinfectant is used in an attempt to prevent the spread of the Ebola virus at a government building in Monrovia, Liberia.

item.title: Break in Fighting Lets International Team Reach Site of Ukraine Crash
item.description: Ukrainian officials said they had suspended offensive operations against pro-Russia rebels to allow the monitors to reach the site safely.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER and ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier and vehicles from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe.

item.title: Gaza Cease-Fire Collapses; Israeli Soldier Is Captured
item.description: A humanitarian cease-fire in the Gaza conflict collapsed hours after it came into effect, with the Israeli military announcing that a soldier appeared to have been captured by Palestinian militants.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and FARES AKRAM
item.media:description: Smoke and flames emerge in Rafah following the collapse of a cease-fire on Friday.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Will the Economy Save Cameron?
item.description: Britain has finally made up the ground lost since the 2008 crash, but that does not assure electoral success for the Conservative Party.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW D’ANCONA

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Africa’s Slide Toward Disaster
item.description: A U.S.-Africa summit meeting needs to address how American policies have fostered a culture of abuse and rebellion.
item.dc:creator: By HELEN EPSTEIN

item.title: Opinion: South Korea’s Education System Hurts Students
item.description: South Korean education produces ranks of overachieving students who pay a stiff price in health and happiness.
item.dc:creator: By SE-WOONG KOO

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Research Plan on Bear Bile Medicine Is Hailed by Animal Activists
item.description: Shanghai Kaibao Pharmaceutical has told its investors that its research project to develop a bear bile equivalent using poultry bile had received the support of the Chinese central government.
item.dc:creator: By SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:description: A bear at a farm owned by Guizhentang Pharmaceutical, which makes tonics from bear bile.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Videos Capture Terror of Deadly Taiwan Explosions
item.description: On cellphones, security monitors and dashboard cameras, the residents of Kaohsiung captured the terrifying series of explosions that rocked their city.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Cease-Fire in Gaza Conflict Takes Effect as Talks Are Set
item.description: The United States and the United Nations announced the 72-hour pause early Friday, a diplomatic bolt-from-the-blue that will set the stage for arduous negotiations between Israel and Hamas.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Family members mourned on Thursday in Tel Aviv at the grave of Staff Sgt. Guy Algranati, 20, who was killed on Wednesday.

item.title: Julio Grondona, Argentine Soccer Chief, Dies at 82
item.description: Mr. Grondona, the combative head of Argentina’s soccer association for 35 years, becoming one of the most powerful figures in FIFA.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: Julio Grondona, right, with Diego Maradona in 2008. Despite their feuds, Maradona expressed his condolences this week.

item.title: World Briefing: Thailand: Military Junta Appoints Interim Legislature
item.description: Thailand’s junta, which took power on May 22, appointed a 200-member interim legislature on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Greece: Government Aids Evacuations From Libya
item.description: A Greek government official said that a merchant vessel had been chartered by the Chinese government for the evacuation of hundreds of its citizens, but gave no further details.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Russia: Snowden Waiting for Extension of Asylum
item.description: The temporary asylum status of Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor accused of leaking secret documents, has expired in Russia.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: India: Dozens of Villagers Still Missing After Landslide
item.description: Rescue workers pulled eight survivors from the mud a day after a huge landslide hit the village of Malin in the Pune district of Maharashtra State in western India.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR

item.title: World Briefing: Norway: As Threat Eases, Terrorism Alert Is Called Off
item.description: Norway’s government called off a weeklong terrorism alert on Thursday, saying an attack by a militant Islamist group with combat training in Syria was no longer seen as imminent.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Azerbaijan: Government Detains Prominent Activist
item.description: Leyla Yunus, a prominent human rights activist in Azerbaijan, was jailed for three months on Thursday pending a trial.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Gas Suspected in Fatal Blasts That Jolted a City in Taiwan
item.description: At least 25 people were killed and more than 260 injured when the southern city of Kaohsiung, Taiwan’s second largest, was rocked by blasts that sent flames surging into the streets.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Suspected gas explosions on Thursday night killed at least 24 people in Kaohsiung, Taiwan.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Separating the Flies From the Tigers in Beijing Zoo Corruption Case
item.description: The corruption case against a former deputy director of the notoriously grim Beijing Zoo has raised the most unlikely questions.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Visitors feeding a giraffe at the Beijing Zoo. Accusations of corruption against a zoo official prompted some to ask if he could have profited at the animals' expense.

item.title: Tensions Escalate Between Israel and a Second Party in Gaza: The United Nations
item.description: Agency officials are enraged by strikes on its facilities and mounting civilian casualties in Gaza, while Israel accuses the United Nations of playing down Hamas’s role in the conflict.
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: American Held in North Korea Says Health Is Failing
item.description: A pro-North Korea newspaper quoted Kenneth Bae, an imprisoned American missionary, as saying that he felt abandoned by the United States.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: School Shelters Offer Limited Safety, and Even Less Comfort
item.description: Life for about 200,000 people packed into more than 80 schools serving as shelters in Gaza is full of deprivation and discomfort.
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: About 200,000 displaced people in Gaza have packed into more than 80 schools run by the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, which cares for refugees.

item.title: Inquiry by C.I.A. Affirms Spying on Senate Panel
item.description: The inspector general’s account of how the C.I.A. secretly monitored a congressional committee charged with supervising its activities touched off angry criticism from members of the Senate.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI and CARL HULSE
item.media:description: John O. Brennan, the C.I.A. director, apologized to two senators in connection with the penetration of a computer network.

item.title: Weak Links in China’s Food Chain
item.description: The OSI Group, one of the top meat producers in the United States with more than $6 billion in sales and about 20,000 employees in 17 countries, is enveloped in a food safety scandal in China.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHANIE STROM
item.media:description: Workers processing food at Shanghai Husi Food, a unit of OSI Group.
